results.title: The Doors
results.creator_credit: Oliver Stone, A. Kitman Ho, Bill Graham, Sasha Harari, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Bill Graham Films
results.brief_description: With this biography of rock group The Doors, and in particular the excesses of lead singer and poet Jim Morrison, Oliver Stone’s obesession with documenting the cultural shifts in America in the 1960s found its perfect subject. Val Kilmer is engaging as Morrison, a young film student who becomes attracted to the promise and liberation of acid-tinged Haight-Ashbury. The formation of The Doors coincided with the LSD experimentation and the counter-cultural revolution in the American underground. Stone traces the band’s increasing popularity, their acceptance by the New York avant-garde, including Warhol’s Factory and Morrison’s decline through drug-abuse. As the band falls apart, only Morrison’s identification with Native American spirituality offers an escape from the materialist Hell he is in. This intense and kinetic film is both a celebration of counter-cultural revolution and a sad lament for its corruption. Co-starring Meg Ryan, Kyle MacLachlan, Michael Madsen and a cameo by Billy Idol.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oliver Stone, A. Kitman Ho, Bill Graham, Sasha Harari, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Bill Graham Films

results.title: The Door
results.creator_credit: Josie Keys, Jo-Anne McGowan and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The removal of a teenager’s bedroom door by her frugal step father (he has insisted the family live on weet-bix for the last three years) is emblematic of family tension in this telling film about the perils of adolescent years, and the lack of communication within the family unit. Cast includes Barry Otto, Penne Hackforth-Jones and Inge Hornstra.

results.title: The Doom generation (D)
results.creator_credit: Gregg Araki, Andrea Sperling and Why not productions
results.brief_description: The second part in Gregg Araki’s ‘Teen apocalypse’ trilogy (“Totally fucked up” and “Nowhere” complete the trilogy), “The Doom generation” wryly proclaims itself in its opening credits as being a ‘heterosexual movie’, then boldly proceeds to be anything but. This deliriously violent road movie chronicles the doomed adventures of nihilistic trio Amy (Rose McGowan), Jordan (James Duval) and Xavier (Jonathon Schaech), who unwittingly become outlaws after a botched and bloody convenience store robbery. The three hit the road and along the way journey into the dark recesses of the American psyche, which is populated by senseless violence, right wing fascists, and surreal urban landscapes. Considered to be one of the main purveyors of ‘Queer cinema’, Araki’s bleak vision of bored and aimless youth is not without pleasure, reveling in acidic one liners, offbeat pop culture cameo’s, an abundance of sex, and a gleeful disrespect for the American mainstream. Cast includes Parker Posey, Heidi Fleiss, Cress Williams, Dustin Nguyen, Margaret Cho, Christopher Knight, Perry Farrell and Amanda Bearse.

results.title: The Domino
results.creator_credit: Robert Stenhouse, Hugh Macdonald and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: An individual is working happily by himself when he is increasingly interrupted by proliferating bureaucracy that eventually totally thwarts his capacity to work. This animated cartoon is an illustration of any activity that loses its originality or purpose when support services and administration become an end in themselves. An entertainment on a universal theme.

results.title: The Dolphin kick
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and Jorhal Pictures
results.brief_description: A swimmer, an underwater camera, and carefully devised teaching demonstrations introduce the new swimming technique known as the dolphin or fishtail kick. Analysing the body movements used in this technique, the film stresses the importance of practice for mastery of this efficient, speedy kick. From this kick, the Butterfly Stroke was developed.

results.title: The Dolphin's gift
results.creator_credit: Kim Kindersley, Victoria Zr. Cotton and Zari Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by John Hurt, this beautifully photographed program introduces Fungi, a bottle-nosed dolphin who lives at the mouth of Dingle Harbour, County Kerry in south west Ireland. Fungi has been charming local people and visitors to County Kerry for six years, though why he came to the harbour is a mystery to locals and experts alike. We are introduced to local inhabitants who share their thoughts and feelings about Fungi and the precarious nature of the survival of dolphin’s around the globe.

results.title: The Dolmetsch Story. Part 3. Making music
results.creator_credit: Fanelodge Productions and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: Final part in a three part series. This film is devoted to the music played and recorded in the Dolmetsch family and also in their museum. It captures the authentic sound of various instruments, which include violas, recorders, harpsicords, virginals, octavinas, spinets and fortepianos. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: The Dolmetsch story. Part 2. Viols and fortepiano
results.creator_credit: Fanelodge Productions and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: Part two of a three part series. Dr Carl Dolmetsch describes the history of the viola da gamba and demonstrates how it is played. Shows its construction in the Dolmetsch workshops, along with some priceless instruments in their museum. The fortepiano is described and demonstrated and we see a recital by the Dolmetschs and Joseph Saxby. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: The Dolmetsch story. Part 1. Recorders
results.creator_credit: Fanelodge Productions and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: Part one of a series of three films. Carl Dometsch, probably the greatest recorder player of all time, is head of the Dolmetsch workshops in Haslemere where many ancient musical instruments have been reconstructed and copied. Dr Dolemetsch describes the history of the recorder and demonstrates the musical qualities of each member of the recorder family. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: The Doll's house. - Edited version
results.creator_credit: Patrick Garland, Hillard Elkins and Paramount Communications
results.brief_description: An edited version of the feature film based on Ibsen’s feminist play of the same name. Set in the 1890’s, it concerns a woman’s attempt to find a role in society for herself apart from those of wife and mother. Stars Claire Bloom, Anthony Hopkins, Denholm Elliott, Anna Massey.
